talk.start.para: On the 18th February, the honorable member for Wilmot (Mr. Guy) asked the following question, without notice:-

quote.para: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Customs whether it is a fact that the price of firewood in Tasmania was fixed by the Prices Commissioner after consultation with and at the request of the Tasmanian Forestry Department?

question.para: The Minister for Trade and Customs has furnished the following answer:‚Äî

quote.para: The Tasmanian Government firewood authorities are in constant touch .with the position in that State, and the prices eventually approved by the Commonwealth Prices Com missioner were recommended by the Deputy Prices Commissioner, Hobart, after consultation with the Government's representatives.

question.para: On the 12th February, the honorable member for Bass (Mr. Barnard) made a lengthy statement on the prices of firewood in Tasmania, and concluded by stating‚Äî

quote.para: I hope my remarks will be brought to the notice of the Prices Commissioner, and that he will review the matter, or at least supply some more substantial information to justifyhis action.

question.para: On the 17th February, the honorable member asked the following question, without notice:‚Äî

quote.para: Last week, I asked a question regarding the increased costs of firewood in tbe city of Launceston, and I was advised that the increase, amounting to over 75 per cent., was due to higher wages for wood-cuttere, and higher costs of transport. Since then I have been advised that music teachers are forbidden to increase their charges by more than 25 .per cent., which corresponds with the increased cost of living. How does the Minister for Trade and Customer reconcile the increase of over 75 per cent. in the price of cut firewood with the increase of only 25 per cent. in the fees of music teachers?

question.para: The remarks of the honorable member have been brought under the notice of the Minister for Trade and Customs, who has provided the following answer:‚Äî

quote.para: The honorable memher for Bass (Mr. Barnard) recently made several referenced to the prices of firewood in Launceston, and variously estimated the increases granted at To per cent, and nearly 100 per cent. He has asked for an explanation of tlie increases aud also for a reconciliation of them with a 25 per cent, increase of fees allowed to music teachers.

In the first place, it is pointed out that, although an examination of the price figures might suggest that an increase of 75 per cent, had taken place iu firewood prices, in actual fact, owing to a change in the relationship of cubic feet and ton weight, con sumers are receiving at least one-third more weight of firewood at present than under the old price. This is based on the estimate of tlie State Government's firewood officers, on whose recommendation prices were advanced.

When this new condition is expressed in terms of price, the percentage increase in the price of firewood is lose than 334 per cent., and is not " nearly 100 per cent." This increase, as has already been pointed nut in an earlier reply to the honorable member, has been amply justified by increased costs. Transport costs, have greatly increased by use of producer-gas units and by reason of the areas close to the cities being cut out, necessitating longer trips, a trend hastened by tbe activities of charcoal-burners. Moreover, the firewood industry was in some respects a sweated trade, and unemployed workers turned to cutting as a means ot earning at least something. Wages paid prior to the outbreak of war were considerably less than the basic wage, and under present con ditions of high earning capacity, a reasonable return must be provided for the wage-earners iu the industry, or firewood will be in short supply, a condition which has already obtained iu certain areas. The Premier of Tasmania has stated that his officers consider that fire wood would not be supplied to Launceston in sufficient quantities without the increase of price.

These, facts should be sufficient to show that not only has the increase of tho price of firewood been entirely justified, but also that a difficult situation arising from short supplies has been averted.

The comparison made between the prices of firewood and fees for music teaching is surely unique. The two are quite incompatible. In the case of firewood there is a wide range of costs to be considered, including an extension of production to areas not hitherto developed. Other factors of a complex character had also to be considered. The ruling given on music-teaching fees applied to one person only, and the honorable member may not be aware that the lady increased her fees by 50 per cent. at a time when the cost of living had risen by approximately 17 1/2 per cen. An examination of the costs incurred by the music teacher showed that no material increase had taken place, and the allowance by the Prices Commissioner of 25 per cent. increase in fees cannot but be regarded and generous in the circumstances.
